results.title: Who framed Roger Rabbit? (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Robert Zemeckis, Frank Marshall, Robert Watts and Touchstone Pictures
results.brief_description: A magical blend of live-acting and animation that comes off brilliantly due to the super effort by Bob Hoskins in playing to imaginary “co-stars” who were drawn in later. Hoskins plays Eddie Valiant, a has-been gumshoe in the ‘40’s film noir mould who comes out of a self enforced “retirement.” Someone is out to steal Toon Town from the cartoon characters who inhabit the magical land. To get their hands on the valuable property they frame its biggest star, Roger Rabbit for murder. Detective Valiant must solve the case and save the toons. Co-starring Christopher Lloyd, Joanna Cassidy, Stubby Kaye and Charles Fleisher.

results.title: Who cares?
results.brief_description: A dramatised recreation concerning the plight of a homeless teenage boy who has turned to prostitution in order to survive. Set in Sydney’s King Cross area the story tells of the efforts of some high school children to help him and attempts to explain the pressures that can cause a child to get into this situation. Financed by various companies and organisations in Sydney.

results.title: Who cares?
results.brief_description: A personal impression of what happened to the people of the Abercrombie district of Liverpool when they were transplanted en bloc to the monstrosity of suburban, high rise planning. The residents regret the almost overnight obliteration of their old community and resent the unwelcome isolation of their new bewilderment.

results.title: Who cares anyway?
results.brief_description: In this modern world there is little excuse for the squalor in which some of the elderly and neglected live. A group of young volunteers produced this film which takes away the glitter of the cities and exposes the utter wretchedness of Britain’s elderly and hopefully raise awareness of the situation.

results.title: Who can you trust?
results.brief_description: Points out the dangers of children accepting car rides from strangers. A number of situations are shown where a child is tempted to go with a stranger, and what children can do in such situations.

results.title: Who are we? Episode 1. Hands and feet
results.brief_description: Shows hands and feet in animals and humans noting differences in size, shape, number, function, adaptability and effect on performance. Suitable for lower secondary level. No dialogue.

results.title: Who am I?: developing a self-concept
results.brief_description: An adolescent negro works part-time in a night-club as a dishwasher so that he can be near the musicians and foster his desire to play the saxophone. However, both his school and dishwashing suffers in his quest for recognition as a saxophonist. Raises issues surrounding work priorities, self concept and the expectations of parents, teachers and peers. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Who's who (TEFC)
results.brief_description: An approach to integrating pre-school and primary school children. Illustrates the way the functions of pre-school can be used in early education centres and still ensure that the skills and content areas are adequately covered for years one and two

results.title: Who's running this school?
results.creator_credit: Jack Zalkalns, John Honey, Tasmania. Education Dept. and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Investigates some of the problems of school administration and management by focusing upon a dramatized presentation of one of the first days in the job of Annie Probert, a newly appointed school principal. Although she is not feeling well, her day looks fairly simple. However, as the days develops, unexpected problems intervene and Annie becomes a victim of the multiple expectations that are a universal hazard of the job. Useful in the areas of decision making, conflict resolution, time management and leadership.

results.title: Who's in control (NP)
results.creator_credit: Mark Davis, ABC-TV (Australia), Monash University and Open Learning Agency of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Everybody’s business: management in action (NP)”.
To carry out a plan or implement a decision a degree of organisation needs to occur. What individuals do (job design), how people relate formally to one another (organisational structure) and how this gets co-ordinated are the essential organising activities. At the same time, mechanisms to establish if the planning, organising, motivating, etc. is achieving what intended to occur. Self correcting control or control followed by corrective action needs to be built into all management processes.
